q: What are the symptoms of ovulation pain?
a: Ovulation pain often feels like a dull pain or sharp sudden twinges, lasts from a few minutes to 1 or 2 days, happens about 14 days before a period, only affects 1 side of your tummy at a time, and switches sides each time, depending on which ovary releases an egg. You may also have a little vaginal bleeding or discharge during ovulation.

q: What are the causes of ovulation pain?
a: Ovulation pain is caused by the ovary releasing the egg. Some conditions that may cause a similar pain include conditions that affect the womb or ovaries such as endometriosis and ovarian cysts, some sexually transmitted infections (STIs) such as chlamydia, scar tissue (adhesions) from surgery you've had near the ovaries, such as a caesarean section, and an ectopic pregnancy.

q: When should I seek urgent medical advice for ovulation pain?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if the pain is severe and painkillers have not helped, the pain keeps coming back, or if you think you may be pregnant. You can call 111 or get help from 111 online.

q: What treatments are available for ovulation pain?
a: If ovulation is the only cause of your pain and it's not severe, a warm bath or painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen may be all you need. A GP may advise contraception to stop you from ovulating, such as the contraceptive pill or a contraceptive implant. If a GP suspects a different cause, they may refer you for tests or to see a specialist.

q: Can I take painkillers for ovulation pain?
i: Yes, you can take painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen for ovulation pain.

q: What should I do if I have severe ovulation pain that does not respond to painkillers?

q: How can I manage mild ovulation pain?
a: If ovulation is the only cause of your pain and it's not severe, you can try taking a warm bath or using over-the-counter painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen. These methods may help alleviate the discomfort. However, it's always advisable to consult with a GP for personalized advice.

q: Can contraception help with ovulation pain?
a: Yes, a GP may recommend contraception to prevent ovulation and reduce ovulation pain. Options may include the contraceptive pill or a contraceptive implant. However, it's important to discuss with a healthcare provider to determine the most suitable method for you.

q: What should I do if my GP suspects something else is causing the ovulation pain?
a: If your GP suspects that something other than ovulation is causing your pain, they may refer you for further tests or to see a specialist. The appropriate treatment will depend on the underlying cause identified through the examination and investigations.

q: Can ovulation pain last for more than a few days?
a: Ovulation pain typically lasts for a short duration, usually a few minutes to 1 or 2 days. If you experience pain lasting longer than this, it's recommended to consult with a healthcare professional for further evaluation.

q: Is vaginal bleeding or discharge normal during ovulation?
a: Yes, some women may experience a small amount of vaginal bleeding or discharge during ovulation. This is considered normal and usually nothing to worry about.

q: Is it normal for ovulation pain to occur on only one side of the tummy?
a: Yes, it is common for ovulation pain to affect only one side of the tummy at a time. The side may alternate depending on which ovary releases an egg during the menstrual cycle.

q: How can I determine if the pain I'm experiencing is due to ovulation?
i: If you experience pain around 14 days before your expected period, lasting for a short duration and following the symptoms of ovulation pain, it is likely to be ovulation pain.
